text: Bring forth with thee every living thing that is with thee, of all flesh, both of fowl, and of cattle, and of every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth; that they may breed abundantly in the earth, and be fruitful, and multiply upon the earth.
text_kjv: Bring forth with thee every living thing that is with thee, of all flesh, both of fowl, and of cattle, and of every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth; that they may breed abundantly in the earth, and be fruitful, and multiply upon the earth.
text_niv: Bring out every kind of living creature that is with you—the birds, the animals, and all the creatures that move along the ground—so they can multiply on the earth and be fruitful and increase in number upon it.”
text_esv: Bring out with you every living thing that is with you of all flesh — birds and animals and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth — that they may swarm on the earth, and be fruitful and multiply on the earth.”
text_nlt: Release all the animals — the birds, the livestock, and the small animals that scurry along the ground — so they can be fruitful and multiply throughout the earth.”
text_msg: And take all the animals with you, the whole menagerie of birds and mammals and crawling creatures, all that brimming prodigality of life, so they can reproduce and flourish on the Earth."
text_nasb: 'Bring out with you every living thing of all flesh that is with you, birds and animals and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth, that they may breed abundantly on the earth, and be fruitful and multiply on the earth.'
context: Genesis 8:17 occurs immediately after the great flood recedes, marking a new beginning for humanity and all living creatures. The historical and cultural context is rooted in ancient Near Eastern creation and flood narratives, where similar themes of divine judgment and subsequent repopulation exist. While the Genesis account is unique in its monotheistic focus and moral dimension, it shares parallels with stories like the Epic of Gilgamesh, which also features a catastrophic flood and a hero tasked with saving life. Ancient societies were deeply dependent on agriculture and animal husbandry, making the command to 'breed abundantly' incredibly significant for the survival and prosperity of the post-flood world. The covenant God made with Noah emphasizes the sanctity of life and the responsibility humanity has towards the animal kingdom. The concept of 'fruitful and multiply' echoes the initial blessing given to Adam and Eve (Genesis 1:28), indicating a restoration of God's original design for creation. Noah's ark, constructed with meticulous detail, was a testament to both God's judgment and his mercy. The command to release the animals was not just about biological repopulation; it symbolized the renewal of God's covenant with creation, promising never again to destroy all life in such a manner. The verse highlights the importance of both human and animal life in God's plan. The specific categories of animals listed ('fowl,' 'cattle,' 'creeping things') encompass the entirety of the animal kingdom known to the ancient Israelites, emphasizing the comprehensive scope of God's restorative work.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 8:17 is a pivotal verse demonstrating God's grace and commitment to the continuation of life after judgment. It illustrates that God's judgment, while severe, is never absolute destruction but always carries the potential for redemption and renewal. The command to 'bring forth' the animals signifies God's active role in restoring the earth's biodiversity and re-establishing the natural order. 'Breed abundantly' and 'be fruitful, and multiply' are not merely biological imperatives, but divine blessings that reflect God's life-giving power and his desire for creation to flourish. This verse is a direct parallel to God's original command to Adam and Eve in Genesis 1:28, reaffirming the inherent value and purpose of creation. It points towards the concept of covenant theology, where God establishes a lasting relationship with humanity and creation, promising to uphold the natural order. The emphasis on all creatures, 'of all flesh,' highlights the interconnectedness of all life and God's care for every living thing. This verse foreshadows the future covenants God will make with humanity, including the Abrahamic and Mosaic covenants, which are all rooted in God's promise of blessing and provision. It also anticipates the ultimate renewal of creation promised in the New Testament, where all things will be made new. The act of releasing the animals is an act of faith on Noah's part, trusting in God's promise that the earth is now safe for habitation and procreation. The verse provides a powerful counter-narrative to the destructive forces of sin and judgment, emphasizing God's enduring love and commitment to his creation.
application: Genesis 8:17 calls us to actively participate in God's ongoing work of creation care and stewardship. We are charged with protecting biodiversity and ensuring the sustainability of our planet for future generations. This means advocating for responsible environmental policies, reducing our carbon footprint, and supporting conservation efforts. Practically, this can involve simple actions like recycling, reducing waste, planting trees, and supporting organizations dedicated to protecting endangered species. We must recognize the inherent value of all living creatures, not just those that are useful to us, and treat them with respect and compassion. The command to 'breed abundantly' can be interpreted metaphorically as a call to cultivate life in all its forms – nurturing relationships, fostering creativity, and promoting justice. We should seek to create environments where others can thrive and reach their full potential. This verse also challenges us to be agents of restoration in broken and hurting communities. Just as Noah released the animals to repopulate the earth, we should work to rebuild lives and communities that have been affected by disaster, injustice, or oppression. This can involve volunteering our time, donating to charitable organizations, or advocating for policies that promote equality and opportunity. Furthermore, the verse reminds us that God's blessings often come through participation. We are not merely passive recipients of God's grace but active participants in bringing about his kingdom on earth. We must trust in God's promise of renewal and work diligently to create a world that reflects his love and justice. We should also apply this to our personal lives, seeking to be fruitful and multiply in our spiritual growth, our relationships, and our vocations. This verse should inspire us to live lives of purpose and meaning, contributing to the flourishing of both humanity and the natural world.
prayer: Sovereign God, Creator of all things, we thank you for your grace and mercy, shown to Noah and all creation after the great flood. Thank you for your promise to never again destroy all life in such a way, a testament to your enduring love. We confess that we have not always been good stewards of the earth you entrusted to us. Forgive us for our negligence and wastefulness. Empower us to live lives that honor your creation, to protect its beauty and diversity, and to ensure its sustainability for generations to come. Help us to be agents of renewal and restoration in our communities, working to rebuild lives and heal brokenness. May we be fruitful and multiply in all that we do, bringing glory to your name and contributing to the flourishing of your kingdom on earth. We ask for wisdom and strength to live out your commands. In Jesus' name, amen.

faqs.answer: The specific categories represented the totality of the animal kingdom as understood in the ancient Near East. It wasn't a scientific classification but a comprehensive way of saying *all* animals were to be released and repopulate the Earth. It emphasizes the all-encompassing nature of God's restorative act.
